evidence: In this study, we have developed a NbTaTiV refractory HEA with a single body-centered-cubic (BCC) structure using an integrated experimental and theoretical approach. Importantly, results indicate that this HEA exhibits the high yield strength and ductility at both room and high temperatures (up to 900 °C). The typical dendrite microstructure was observed, which is caused by the elemental segregation during the solidification in the as-cast condition. The structural inhomogeneity and chemical segregation were completely eliminated by the proper homogenization treatment at 1,200 ºC for 3 days.

microstructure: A single BCC solid solution is predicted to form with the bulk composition of NbTaTiV. As the homogenization temperature and duration increase, an apparent microstructural variation is observed. The atomic-scale distribution of elements for the homogenized sample was measured, revealing a uniform distribution of alloying elements with near-equal atomic concentrations.
type_of_test: In-situ neutron-diffraction, mechanical tests at room and elevated temperatures
evidence: A single BCC solid solution is predicted to form with the bulk composition of NbTaTiV. As the homogenization temperature and duration increase, an apparent microstructural variation is observed. The atomic-scale distribution of elements for the homogenized sample was measured, revealing a uniform distribution of alloying elements with near-equal atomic concentrations.

The elevated-temperature compressive tests were performed up to 900 °C at a strain rate of 1 x 10 -3 s -1 for the homogenized NbTaTiV alloy, and the stress-strain curves are illustrated in Fig.  6 . As the temperature increases, the yield strength gradually decreases from 1,273 MPa (RT) to 688 MPa (900 °C).

In case of a single BCC phase HEA, the strengthening components in the NbTaTiV alloy due to the lattice and modulus distortions are estimated to be 431 MPa, and 227 MPa, respectively. This result indicates that the lattice distortions are likely to be the dominant strengthening factor rather than modulus distortions in this alloy system.

Figure 4(a) presents the compressive engineering stress-strain curves of the as-cast and homogenization-treated NbTaTiV alloys at RT with a strain rate of 1 × 10 -3 s -1 .
